blind caecum. As in the larva, there are a number of 
Malpighian tubules situated at the posterior end of 
the stomach.
<u>The Salivary Glands <\u>.
The secretion of the salivary glands in the imago is 
alkaline to test papers; and readily converts starch 
into glucose. The presence of glucose was proved by the 
formation of red cuprous oxide by the action of 
Fehling’s solution. It has, however, no action on 
fibrin. When the secretion was distilled in a 
miniature retort (made of glass tubing) with 
dilute sulphuric acid, the distillate showed the 
presence of sulphocyanates on the addition of 
ferric chloride. The secretion of these glands yields 
a small quantity of ash, which contains calcium 
phosphate.
From these investigations, it is proved that the salivary 
glands of the imago of <u>Pontia <\u> secrete a fluid
